response.content:
Hey Kuldeep, thank you for your feedback. It's a tricky one, this is the Advanced course which builds upon the introductory course. In order to make the transition smooth between courses, we use the same app (which we explain thoroughly in our provided e-book and intro section). We do not recommend (in fact, we discourage) students from taking this course first. Also, taking this course without knowledge of REST APIs is not recommended.

With that said, we hope you enjoyed it nonetheless!

results.content: Jose Salvatierra has always been my favorite teacher. As expected, he has done justice to this course. I couldn't expect anything less. He covers everything with great detail. I recommend this course to everyone who wants to go further in building professional REST APIs

results.content:
This is an awesome course. 
This is the course you take when you are ready to become a senior Flask developer.
Even though it is not a beginner course, Jose takes his time to explain every concept and every topic in a very beginner friendly way. It is easy to follow and I have had no problems at all understanding the concepts.

I do advice that you take the beginner course or at least have a good foundation knowledge of API development with flask. 

It's not just about API here but also some more tips, trick and best practices for python development in general.

I absolutely recommend this course to anyone looking to add and update their knowledge on Flask and API development.

results.content: This is my fifth course by the Teclado team and 72th course on Udemy. Compared to earlier courses it has chose your own adventure style with more or less independent sections instead of a continuous journey. As always, it is easy to follow instructions along with lots of opportunity to code. In particular, I appreciate the modern coding style, for example, with use of type hinting and f-strings.

results.content:
This course takes a pre-existing API and makes transformations to it to update to an API that would more likely be in use in a professional environment. Because of the updates, it's harder to build a mental model of a Python Flask API.

I have taken the course that this course extends upon, twice, and it follows a similar pattern--making extensions and changes to an already developed app. In fairness, you start off developing a simple Python Flask API. However, because of this mode of teaching, I'm simply left confused and not sure what the initial requirements are for building an API with Python and Flask.

It would be far better to build a small API, then build a more complicated API from scratch, then build a professional-like API from scratch, each time starting anew, so that the student can build a complete mental model and get repetitions writing APIs and writing Python code.

Also, please don't speed up the videos! The act of actually writing code (or Postman) tests is critical to learning. I think this is also part of the reason why it's harder to build a mental model of what's happening in the application (we have not written enough code).

If Stephen Grider had a Python course, I would take it, as this is the teaching model he follows. I don't feel much more confident about Flask APIs after taking the pre-course or being halfway complete with this course. Maybe it will just come with time.
results.content_html:

However, because of this mode of teaching, I'm simply left confused and not sure what the initial requirements are for building an API with Python and Flask.

It would be far better to build a small API, then build a more complicated API from scratch, then build a professional-like API from scratch, each time starting anew, so that the student can build a complete mental model and get repetitions writing APIs and writing Python code.

Also, please don't speed up the videos! The act of actually writing code (or Postman) tests is critical to learning. I think this is also part of the reason why it's harder to build a mental model of what's happening in the application (we have not written enough code).

If Stephen Grider had a Python course, I would take it, as this is the teaching model he follows. I don't feel much more confident about Flask APIs after taking the pre-course or being halfway complete with this course. Maybe it will just come with time.

results.content: The course covered a lot of interesting topics and was reasonably detailed, however I felt that it was also too fast and it was difficult to keep interest due to it being so fast. I'm also not sure if using all of those Flask libraries makes sense in the long run as there seems to be so many different libraries that might not even be maintained anymore.

response.content:
Hey Oliver, thank you very much for your comments and suggestions. Since this is the Advanced course, we do go a bit faster and want to cover more features to include in your REST APIs.

I see your point about libraries potentially not being maintained, but as libraries become old and deprecated, new ones take their place. For example, we've seen this with Flask-OAuthlib and the newer Authlib. They're basically the same, and changing from one to another is a matter of a few minutes (I've done this myself!).

That's why this course is for teaching you concepts and how to use them, but not so much about tying to specific libraries.

Thanks again for your comment!

Kind regards,
Jose
response.content_html:
Hey Oliver, thank you very much for your comments and suggestions. Since this is the Advanced course, we do go a bit faster and want to cover more features to include in your REST APIs.

I see your point about libraries potentially not being maintained, but as libraries become old and deprecated, new ones take their place. For example, we've seen this with Flask-OAuthlib and the newer Authlib. They're basically the same, and changing from one to another is a matter of a few minutes (I've done this myself!).

That's why this course is for teaching you concepts and how to use them, but not so much about tying to specific libraries.

Thanks again for your comment!

Kind regards,
Jose

results.content:
so far working with marshmallow is a total nightmare each video something changes and my code wont run properly
its doesnt seem kind of systematic like the previous course
the instructor uses old library versions and syntax whic makes it really complicated to learn how to use
and the instructor's own code doesnt actually work
and he doesnt respond to your question quickly
honestly i woldnt recomment this course to anyone

response.content:
Hey Fares, thank you for your feedback. When we start getting into advanced topics, things can change and break. Marshmallow requires a 3-line change to work fully with a recent breaking change of Flask-Marshmallow and Marshmallow-SQLAlchemy (this is detailed in the course).

We respond to questions often, although not normally within 24 hours. All the code for the course is provided in GitHub.

Kind regards,
Jose

results.content: Great course. Got a lot a stuff to take from it. The prequel course for this one is also awesome for fundamentals and this course takes it to another level. You'll need to complete the python flask rest api course before this one to get the most out of this course in case you don't have previous experience on flask. Plus this course gives a nice boost project for your resume if you are a fresher. Thanks Jose!

You can absolutely have endpoints like /stores/3/items! Please ask in the Course Q&A if you're not sure how to do it!

Kind regards,
Jose

results.content: If you're new to API design, I recommend you take the first course, for the detailed walkthroughs. The clean code, best practices, and alignment with popular modules is wonderful. results.content:
This is my 2nd Teclado course. High quality, well organized, well explained. 
My only feedback is that there is too much refactoring . I think there are points in which it would have been cleaner to code stuff from scratch. Marshmallow section is a clear example

response.content:
Hey Carlos, thank you for taking the time to leave a review! I'm glad you're enjoying the course, and thank you for the feedback.

It's always a difficult decision with an advanced course, whether we should start things from scratch or not. For this course, we assume students have knowledge of using reqparse for the applications, so we didn't want to completely forget about that. That's why we started off using reqparse, and in the Marshmallow section we did a step by step refactor—as opposed to starting from scratch.

Thank you nonetheless for taking the time. I appreciate it!

Kind regards,
Jose
response.content_html:
Hey Carlos, thank you for taking the time to leave a review! I'm glad you're enjoying the course, and thank you for the feedback.

It's always a difficult decision with an advanced course, whether we should start things from scratch or not. For this course, we assume students have knowledge of using reqparse for the applications, so we didn't want to completely forget about that. That's why we started off using reqparse, and in the Marshmallow section we did a step by step refactor—as opposed to starting from scratch.

Thank you nonetheless for taking the time. I appreciate it!

Kind regards,
Jose
